narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A basic understanding of Spanish and Latin America
How to speak intro spanish and how to memorize, in terms of both the literal skill and motivation.
The basics of Spanish
Started with no Spanish skills at all, finished the semester feeling comfortable with basic conversation/reading/writing skills
Spanish! Enough to describe and talk about most simple things in some manner. Gave a framework also so that I could learn more Spanish from practice talking/listening.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was engaging, and it is not easy to take a day off in class (which is beneficial). Relevant assignments and interesting/fun projects kept the course enjoyable. I do not have any complaints about the class.

The course was excellent. I really liked how small the class size was because I felt like a got a lot of personal conversation time. I think it could be improved by cutting down on the online homework and replacing it with more interactive assignments.

Strengths: The daily use of Spanish (either through classes or through the HW) forces you to learn the language at a rapid pace
Weaknesses: The examples used in class were often well beyond the level of material learned (e.g., using vocabulary or grammar that we had not learnt yet). Although I understand that learning comes from struggling, it sometimes felt that the gap was too big.

I loved the variety of activities. I thought SuperSite was very helpful for reinforcing course material. I didn't like the cultural project or the cultural readings that were mixed in - I would have preferred less time on culture and more on practicing speaking. I didn't mind the textbook, but I know some of my classmates really found it difficult to follow.
Great curriculum, teacher, students, and organization.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It's a little tougher learning a language online than in person, but I thought the course was well-adapted. Our profesor did a great job of keeping class engaging.
The online courses worked well, but I wasn't a huge fan of having to record presentations.

Succeeded: Using breakout rooms to force interactions with other students
Could be improved: After the breakout rooms, limiting the read-outs / sharing by each group of students. Given our low level of Spanish, it was often difficult to understand what everyone was saying, leading to checking out / multi-tasking on our computers. Additionally, I believe that the use of Google Translate during class should be asked to be limited. I believe it often led to people creating sentences that would normally have exceeded their skill level, giving the instructor a false view of where the class was actually at.
SuperSite was great. I also would have appreciated one-on-one sessions with a speaking coach.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would. I really enjoyed it and looked forward to class everyday.
Yes, I felt like I learned a lot of spanish for just one semester.

I would recommend this course to a student who is willing to put in the work. If you are willing to dedicate ~1 hour per day, 5 days a week, you can get a lot out of this course. I was shocked by how quickly I learned. But the course moves very quickly, so I would not recommend it for someone who is not committed to learning Spanish.
Yes it was just an amazing language course, at least with Maria.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: VHL online assignments and lessons; out of class projects and assignments; Canvas modules
Online homework, quizzes, and recordings
N/A
SuperSite
